Instead, the argument is that more control will reduce crime by reducing supply - not elliminating. If this argument is correct, we come to the decision which is more impotrant? That some of the population have the enjoyment and placebo (if our argument is correct) safety of owning a gun, or that less violent crime exists? We're back to freedom vs security again, and in this case I would definitely go for 'security'.

 
 As said before, unless there's some serious proof that banning gun ownership will reduce total death by firearms by a substantial amount that can't possibly be ignored as just another normal fluctuation in year-to-year rates, then there's really not much point in discussing the subject since it's all academic and hypothetical. Sure it's easy to draw the simple conclusion that "no guns = no killing" but in reality nothing is that cut and dry and simple, there's too much to take into account.
 
 
The second argument you hinted at was that gun control will only affect the 'law-abiding citizens'. This, too, is false - otherwise why have any laws at all? Just as with all other laws, introducing the law (and punishment for breaking it) reduces the criminalised activity.

 
 I think Flyboy is the expert here, he's a police officer and has seen the affects gun control has had and how well it works and doesn't work.
 
 
Oh, and apologies - you misunderstood me. '[these must be justified:] Religion to politics via science and philosophy' was meant to be read so that all four things need to be justified - philosophical and scientific ideas included. Generally, it's true that logic/science is used to justify everything, but there is also some interesting philosophical ideas behind the scientific method, which themselves require justification (see the Problem of Induction).

 
 I'll tackle this one when I'm not so tired.
